conclusion: The problem involves a detector moving along the positive x-axis with a velocity inversely proportional to its displacement.
The velocity \\( v \\) is inversely proportional to the displacement \\( x \\), expressed as \\( v = \frac{k}{x} \\).
At point B, the velocity \\( v_B = 2 \\) m/s and the displacement \\( x_B = 2 \\) m.
Solving for the constant \\( k \\) gives \\( k = 4 \\).
At point A, the velocity \\( v_A = 4 \\) m/s.
Solving for the displacement at point A gives \\( x_A = 1 \\) m.
The time \\( t \\) taken to move from point A to point B is found by integrating the reciprocal of the velocity function from \\( x_A \\) to \\( x_B \\).
The integral setup is \\( t = \int_{1}^{2} \frac{x}{4} \, dx \\).
Evaluating the integral gives \\( t = \frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{2^2}{2} - \frac{1^2}{2} \right) = \frac{1}{4} \left( 2 - 0.5 \right) = \frac{1}{4} \times 1.5 = 0.375 \\) seconds.
The time it takes for the detector to move from point A to point B is \\( 0.375 \\) seconds.
